summary: Email correspondence between a U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) prosecutor and attorney Nicolas Bourtin regarding a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) filed by a bank concerning entities associated with Jeffrey Epstein. The bank holds approximately $30 million in accounts it wishes to close and is seeking guidance from the government.

persons.name: Nicolas Bourtin
persons.context: Represents a bank that filed a SAR regarding entities associated with Jeffrey Epstein; communicates with the U.S. Attorney's Office about closing accounts holding approximately $30 million.

persons.name: Sharon Cohen Levin
persons.context: Copied on emails between Nicolas Bourtin and the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding the SAR and Epstein-related accounts.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of the Suspicious Activity Report
persons.context: The SAR filed by the bank concerns persons and entities associated with him; his name is central to the financial investigation discussed.

connections.description: Both are attorneys copied on the same legal correspondence regarding the Epstein-related SAR and bank accounts.
Bourtin represents a bank that filed a SAR concerning entities associated with Epstein, placing him in a professional legal context regarding Epstein's financial affairs.

events.title: SAR Filing Regarding Epstein Entities
events.description: A bank, represented by Nicolas Bourtin, files Suspicious Activity Report 2019-43693 concerning persons and entities associated with Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Bank Seeks to Close Epstein-Linked Accounts
events.description: The bank informs the U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) of its intent to close accounts named in the SAR, which hold approximately $30 million, and seeks government guidance.

locations: 125 Broad Street, New York, NY 10004.2498 (Sullivan & Cromwell LLP office)
keyFacts: A bank filed Suspicious Activity Report 2019-43693 concerning persons and entities associated with Jeffrey Epstein.
Accounts of the entities named in the SAR hold approximately $30 million.
The bank wishes to close these accounts and is coordinating with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) before doing so.
The correspondence involves attorneys Nicolas Bourtin and Sharon Cohen Levin, indicating legal and financial scrutiny of Epstein's network after his death.
The document is external correspondence from a law firm to a government prosecutor, highlighting ongoing financial investigations.
